name: man
desc: The man command line is used to display manual pages for commands on Linux. With man, users can learn about command usage, parameters, options, and other information.

-C.name: Display output containing ANSI escape codes as plain text

-D.name: Print the macro definitions used by man

-F.name: Equivalent to the whatis command, ignoring letter case

-K.name: Equivalent to the apropos command, ignoring letter case

-l.name: Print search results one line at a time to the terminal

-L.name: Print search results one line at a time to the terminal, ignoring letter case

-m.name: Search all manpath directories for all manual pages

-r.name: Search all directories in manpath, including subdirectories

-w.name: Do not output results, only show the path of the manual page

-d.name: Specify the manpath directory where man will search for manual pages

-M.name: Similar to the -m option, but only searches the specified manpath directory

-S.name: Specify the manual section to search

content:
Example

  • Display the manual page for the ls command: man ls
  • Display the NAME section for the ls command: man -f ls
  • Display all manual pages related to ls: man -k ls
  • Display the DESCRIPTION section for the ls command: man -d ls
  • Display the OPTIONS section for the ls command: man -h ls
  • Equivalent to the whatis command: man -f ls
  • Display the path of the manual page: man -w ls

Note: Here, the ls command is just an example and can be replaced with any other command.
